ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course introduced me to so much. This course gave me a strong foundation for future pursuits in the philosophy language. The course also developed connections between philosophy of language and contemporary culture, which keeps the material fresh.

An introduction to the philosophies of language, with a focus on (but not limited to) the German tradition. Covered Aristotle/Plato, Humboldt, Herder,, Nietzsche, Hofmannsthal, Freud, Austin, Derrida, Butler, etc. Applied philosophies to the analysis of nontraditional uses of language (e.g. emojis, Dada poetry, other poetry, memes, social media posts, etc.)

Reading and analyzing important works of philosophy of language largely within the German tradition, putting them into historical context, and developing methods of analysis of novel uses of language-esque communication methods (i.e., emojis, memes), expressing them in terms of crises of language.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The discussions were fantastic. The readings were always interesting in one way or another. The central theme of the course was engaging and a constant point of return.

I think time management was a bit of a problem in this course. Expert sessions were a lovely component of each seminar, but I think stricter time limits and group size restrictions would do wonders for the pacing of each seminar session.

Strengths (also in question 9): 1) There seem to be entry points for both people with no prior experience in philosophy (like me) and people already familiar with a lot of the philosophers we read. 2) Sophie does a wonderful job fostering a sense of class community, leading classroom discussions, and motivating students. As a result, the class -- though it was conducted through student presentations  (in addition to some context provided by Sophie) -- functioned wonderfully: students always seemed to want to bring their best to the table. 3) The class is flexible enough that students have the opportunity to explore their own interests, which both enhanced my own learning and helped keep me engaged. 4) Sophie is a knowledgeable, understanding, and wonderful professor! One of the best I've had at Yale. If you have the opportunity to take ANY class with her, you should!!!!!!

Weaknesses: None, except that we often ran out of time/some presentations and discussions had to be cut short. Seminars were often so engaging (even to someone who often just listened and took notes) that the 110 minutes often flew by. (This is saying a lot, as I get bored/distracted quite easily...)

I learned a lot in this course and felt the syllabus was very well thought-through and cohesive. However, I think the time we had in class could have been managed better. This was made significantly more difficult by the number of students in the class ( I hope this demonstrated interest in the class encourages this course being offered again). We often ran out of time due to the expert sessions, and often did not have much time to discuss. I suggest that each student work on one expert session instead of two and that a strict time limit be imposed on the expert sessions. I think blocking out time specifically for seminar-style discussion would also be helpful.

Strengths: fantastic professor, great readings, and engaging discussions. Weaknesses: I would've loved the professor to intervene, moderate and support the in-class discussions a bit more, and the bigger class size felt a bit too cramped sometimes. Also, some more feedback on our written work would've been great.

Readings were super interesting and well chosen. The major problem with the class this semester was that it was too big for a seminar, which made the individual presentations kind of take over in a way that became detrimental to our ability to discuss the texts in depth. It was also annoying that despite the amount of people in the class only a few of them regularly participated, though I dont know what Professor Schweiger could have done to change that.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Some of the texts and concepts are difficult, but discussing them was a joy. There was a lot of room for creativity in every assignment during this course, which I think helped students to confront each text on their own terms.

I would DEFINITELY recommend this course to other students. There seem to be entry points for both people with no prior experience in philosophy (like me) and people already familiar with a lot of the philosophers we read. Sophie also does a wonderful job fostering a sense of class community, leading classroom discussions, and motivating students. As a result, the class -- though it was conducted through student presentations  (in addition to some context provided by Sophie) -- functioned wonderfully: students always seemed to want to bring their best to the table. The class is also flexible enough that students have the opportunity to explore their own interests, which both enhanced my own learning and helped keep me engaged.

Yes, if you're broadly interested in how theories of language have intersected with corresponding crises of meaning, and how we've developed an increasingly comprehensive understanding of the many uses of language.

Yes! Professor Schweiger is great. The caveat is that you really shouldnt take this course if youre not willing to put in the work for it, because discussions were really dampened by the amount of people who just never participated.
Yes, it provided many interesting topics of discussion.
